TopicTitle: How to make a stock propeller SSTO plane?

Articles.Content:
Anyone could make one for me so that I can learn the principle?

Edited July 4, 2018 by Reusables

You want this to be stock? Or using modded propellers?

It has to take off using the propellers?

Edited July 4, 2018 by bewing
It has to be stock, and yes it has to take off using the propellers.

For the propellers, you'll need a separate craft held inside something like a service bay or fairing but free to spin. It'll need to have a bunch of reaction wheels and maybe RTGs (for electric charge generation) to keep spinning. I'd watch this video by Squiddy to get the basics of stock props. It's a bit old but the basics should still work.

Tip: as shown in the video, you can detach your engine, then switch to it and hold down Alt-Q or Alt-E. This will set the trim on the propeller so it'll keep spinning without you having to babysit it.

Once you get too high for the props to have any effect, you can switch to them and hit Alt-X to reset the trim. Then just continue to orbit on rocket power.
I know how to make propellers. SSTO was hard, though.

How much mass can you get off the ground with your props? That's the crucial question for SSTO. Next question is how high can you get it, but that's less important.

Once you're off the ground, you just need enough rocket TWR and fuel to get to orbit. Your craft should be either MK1 or MK3.

Note that the rest of us don't usually bother with stock props, so it's unlikely that any of us have a prop SSTO on hand.  So you might want to supply the craft file for your prop plane, and we can modify it so that it SSTOs.

 

 

Edited July 4, 2018 by bewing

Uhm actually, I found that I did this in the past. I'll just replicate the design.

Sorry!

Just a side note, any rotors will not work in space. No air = no thrust.

You must use rocket or ion engines. Or nuclear engines.
Ofc, I used nuclear engine. Since it's too massive, I'm going to switch to the new MH vacuum engine.
